traces.decision: Live coding demos placed BEFORE the hands-on exercise, not after
traces.reasoning: While 80% of the group has some plotting experience (application level or higher on prerequisites), Alex Chen has zero assessed plotting skills and is missing both direct prerequisites. An inductive approach (exercise-first) would leave Alex completely lost. By front-loading the demos, Alex sees the pattern 4 times before having to reproduce it. Priya and Sofia (who are already at application level) stay engaged because the demos introduce NEW syntax (matplotlib) even though the concepts are familiar.

constraints: 30-minute session — no time for an exploratory phase
teachingWisdom: Warm-up exercises using the same dataset dramatically improve outcomes for mixed-level groups

alternativesConsidered.option: Start with hands-on exercise, then debrief with theory (inductive approach)
alternativesConsidered.whyRejected: Alex would be completely stuck with no reference point. In a 30-minute session, there's no time to recover from a false start. With 4 out of 5 learners at application level, the group could handle this, but Alex's missing prerequisites make it too risky.

alternativesConsidered.option: Start with theory lecture, then demos, then exercise (full deductive)
alternativesConsidered.whyRejected: A theory lecture about chart types would bore Priya and Sofia (who already know Tableau/matplotlib). The energy would die before the exercise. Live coding IS the theory delivery — it's just embedded in demonstration rather than abstraction.

traces.wouldChangeIf: If Alex had completed the prerequisites (import-pandas, install-packages), an inductive exercise-first approach would be stronger for this group. The group's average Bloom's level supports it — it's only Alex's gap that tips the balance.

traces.decision: 12 minutes allocated to the hands-on exercise (40% of total session time)
traces.reasoning: Application-level skills require approximately 15 minutes per the Bloom's baseline, but the group's average readiness on prerequisites is moderate (most have prior experience), so the adjustment factor brings it to ~12 minutes. Teaching wisdom from 18 previous sessions indicates that plotting exercises typically take 10-15 minutes for mixed groups. The 12-minute allocation is the sweet spot — long enough for Alex to get 2 charts working (with Priya's help), short enough to keep Priya/Sofia engaged (they'll finish in 5-7 minutes and move to extensions).

teachingWisdom: Plotting exercises typically take 10-15 min for mixed groups
Hands-on sections run 5-8 min over for beginner groups
constraints: 30-minute total session — exercise gets the lion's share

alternativesConsidered.whyRejected: Alex wouldn't get past chart 1. Even with Priya's help, 8 minutes doesn't leave time for the debugging/error-fixing cycles that beginners inevitably hit. Teaching wisdom says beginners need at least 10 minutes for basic plotting.

Would require cutting the demo phase to 7 minutes (only 2 chart types demoed) or eliminating the wrap-up. The wrap-up is the anchor — it's where 'the one thing' solidifies. Cutting it is a false economy.

traces.wouldChangeIf: If the session were 45 minutes instead of 30, I'd extend to 18 minutes and add a second round ('now try charting different columns'). If Alex had the prerequisites, 10 minutes would be sufficient.

traces.decision: Alex paired with Priya; Nkechi, Marcus, and Sofia work solo
traces.reasoning: Alex needs scaffolding from a peer — the Bloom's gap between Alex (no skills) and Priya (application level) is exactly 1 level in terms of effective competence, because Priya's 0.75 confidence means she's secure but not so far ahead that she'd lose patience. Priya gets the synthesis-level challenge of explaining, which exercises skills she doesn't normally use. Nkechi works solo because she needs to build Python muscle memory — pairing would let her delegate the typing. Marcus works solo because of his accessibility setup (screen magnification, high-contrast) which is optimized for his workflow. Sofia is at a level where independent practice builds confidence.

learnerProfiles: Nkechi Okonkwo (R expert, needs Python syntax practice)
Marcus Johnson (accessibility needs, prefers own setup)
bloomsLevels: Alex: knowledge/below → Priya: application = ~1 level gap
constraints: Marcus has accessibility accommodations — don't disrupt his setup

alternativesConsidered.option: Pair Alex with Sofia instead of Priya
alternativesConsidered.whyRejected: Sofia is at 0.70 confidence — close to Priya's 0.75 — but Sofia's strength is visualization concepts (Tableau), not Python syntax. She'd be less effective at explaining matplotlib code patterns. Priya's higher confidence means she can explain AND troubleshoot syntax errors.

alternativesConsidered.option: Pair Nkechi with Alex (both have gaps)
alternativesConsidered.whyRejected: Nkechi's gap is different from Alex's — she knows the concepts but not the Python syntax. Pairing two learners who both need to learn the syntax creates a 'two confused people' dynamic. One partner needs to be solidly confident.
Alex would likely give up within 3 minutes. With no assessed plotting skills AND missing prerequisites, solo work without scaffolding is a recipe for frustration and shutdown.

traces.wouldChangeIf: If Marcus expressed interest in working with a partner, I'd pair him with Nkechi (complementary skills — his Python is solid, her concepts are strong). If Alex had completed prerequisites, solo work with a reference sheet would be appropriate.

traces.decision: 3-minute 'What story does this data tell?' hook instead of jumping straight to demos
traces.reasoning: The hook serves three purposes: (1) It activates prior knowledge for Sofia and Nkechi, who already understand data visualization conceptually. (2) It gives the educator 3 minutes to walk to Alex's station and help with notebook setup while the group discusses. (3) It creates ownership — when students suggest 'sales over time' as a question, and then the demo shows exactly that, the demo feels like answering their question rather than lecturing at them. Teaching wisdom from previous sessions shows that warm-up exercises using the same dataset dramatically improve outcomes.

learnerProfiles: Sofia Ramirez (Tableau expert, will drive discussion)
bloomsLevels: The hook targets analysis level — choosing chart types for data questions
teachingWisdom: Warm-up exercises using the same dataset dramatically improve outcomes
Engagement drops when sessions start with lecture
constraints: 30 minutes — only 3 min for the hook, can't afford more

alternativesConsidered.option: Skip the hook and start with live coding immediately
alternativesConsidered.whyRejected: Misses the setup window for Alex. Also, students who don't understand WHY they're learning something disengage faster. The hook provides the 'why' — these charts answer YOUR data questions.
In a 30-minute session, 5 minutes is 17% of the session. The marginal benefit of 2 extra minutes of discussion doesn't justify the time cost. Keep it tight.

traces.wouldChangeIf: If this were a 60-minute session, I'd extend to a 5-minute hook with a 'guess the chart type' matching activity. If the group were all beginners (no prior visualization experience), I'd replace the open question with a simpler 'which chart type would you use for X?' multiple choice.

traces.decision: Full talking points with code commentary for each demo, including R-to-Python bridges for Nkechi and accessibility callouts for Marcus
traces.reasoning: The lesson plan is prepared for 'Educator' (no specific profile loaded), so I've defaulted to intermediate-depth content scaffolding: full talking points, suggested verbal asides, and personalized callouts for specific learners. The personalized bridges (R → Python for Nkechi, accessibility rationale for Marcus) serve double duty — they help those learners AND teach the educator how to differentiate instruction for different backgrounds.

learnerProfiles: Nkechi Okonkwo (R expert — needs syntax bridges)
Marcus Johnson (accessibility needs — needs high-contrast, large font)
constraints: No educator profile loaded — defaulting to intermediate depth
educatorProfile: No profile available — using full talking points as default

alternativesConsidered.whyRejected: Without knowing the educator's expertise level, brief bullets risk leaving a novice educator without enough guidance. Intermediate depth (full talking points) is the safe default.

The whole point of the engine is that it knows the group. A generic plan ignores Nkechi's R background (an asset to bridge from) and Marcus's accessibility needs (a requirement to accommodate). The per-learner callouts are what make this plan better than a template.

traces.wouldChangeIf: If an educator profile showed expert-level confidence in python-data-analysis, I'd strip this to timing cues and structural notes only. If it showed novice-level confidence, I'd add anticipated student questions with prepared answers.

traces.decision: Contingencies structured as specific alternatives with step-by-step instructions
traces.reasoning: Without an educator profile, I'm using structured/specific contingencies as the default. Each contingency includes exact code, exact instructions, and exact time savings. This is the structuralist approach — it gives the educator a concrete backup plan they can execute without improvising. If the educator has high improvisation skills, they can adapt these on the fly; if they don't, they have a script.

constraints: No educator profile — defaulting to structured contingencies
teachingWisdom: Students struggle with groupby operations — common confusion point

alternativesConsidered.option: Open-ended contingencies ('pivot to a discussion about why this is hard')
alternativesConsidered.whyRejected: Without knowing the educator's improvisation comfort level, open-ended contingencies are risky. A structuralist educator given 'just discuss it' will freeze. Better to provide specific alternatives that any educator can execute.

traces.wouldChangeIf: If the educator profile showed high improvisation and facilitation strengths (like Marcus Rodriguez's profile), I'd switch to open-ended contingencies: 'Pivot to a discussion about what makes this confusing. Let students share their mental models.' Improvisers thrive with direction, not scripts.

traces.decision: Pre-loaded starter notebook with imports done, rather than having students set up from scratch
traces.reasoning: Alex's missing prerequisites (import-pandas, install-packages) mean that if setup is part of the lesson, Alex would spend the entire 30 minutes just trying to import pandas. The starter notebook sidesteps this by pre-loading the DataFrame, so Alex can focus on plotting — which IS the learning objective. Nkechi's weak import-pandas score (0.55) is also mitigated. This is a 'floor removal' strategy: remove barriers that aren't part of the learning objective so learners can reach the actual content.

bloomsLevels: import-pandas is knowledge-level — not the target
constraints: 30 minutes — zero time for setup troubleshooting

alternativesConsidered.option: Start with a 5-minute setup exercise where students import pandas themselves
alternativesConsidered.whyRejected: 5 minutes = 17% of the session. Alex and Nkechi would consume ALL of it (and likely more). The other 3 students would sit idle. import-pandas isn't the learning objective — basic-plotting is. Don't sacrifice the goal for the prerequisites.

alternativesConsidered.option: Require students to complete setup BEFORE the session (as homework)
alternativesConsidered.whyRejected: Alex is a career changer who may not have the support to troubleshoot Python installation issues at home. If Alex shows up with a broken environment, the entire session is derailed for that learner. The starter notebook is a safety net.

traces.wouldChangeIf: If the learning objective included 'importing libraries' (i.e., import-pandas was a target skill, not just a prerequisite), then a setup exercise would be pedagogically valuable. It's only because import-pandas is a means to an end that we skip it.

traces.decision: 3-minute wrap-up with universal pattern reinforcement instead of a quiz or discussion
traces.reasoning: The 'one thing' for this lesson is the 5-line pattern (plt.plot, title, xlabel, ylabel, show). The wrap-up exists to anchor this pattern in memory. A quiz would create anxiety (Alex just struggled through the exercise). A discussion would diffuse focus. Writing the universal pattern on the whiteboard and saying it aloud — while students see it with fresh eyes from having just USED it — creates the strongest memory encoding. The show-of-hands check ('who got 1 chart? who got 4?') celebrates progress without ranking.

learnerProfiles: Alex Chen (low confidence — needs celebration, not testing)
Priya Sharma (will have all 4 — public recognition motivates her)
bloomsLevels: application level — pattern recognition is the target
teachingWisdom: Pattern reinforcement after hands-on work produces strongest retention
constraints: 3 minutes only — must be punchy and memorable

alternativesConsidered.option: Quick quiz: 'What function makes a histogram?'
alternativesConsidered.whyRejected: Creates anxiety for Alex and Nkechi, who just spent 12 minutes struggling. The wrap-up should feel like a win, not a test. Also, recall-based quizzes don't test application — they test memorization, which is a lower Bloom's level than the lesson objective.

alternativesConsidered.option: Group discussion: 'When would you use each chart type?'
alternativesConsidered.whyRejected: This is an analysis-level activity in a session targeting application level. It's a great activity for the NEXT session, but in the last 3 minutes, it would feel rushed and incomplete. Save it.

traces.wouldChangeIf: In a 45-minute session, I'd add a 5-minute 'gallery walk' where students share their best chart on screen and the group picks a favorite. Social validation reinforces learning and builds community.
